Further reproduction prohibited without permission. 1 Arianne Faber Kolb Todd Olson and Elizabeth Honig ABSTRACT CATALOGUING NATURE IN ART: JAN BRUEGHEL THE ELDER’S PARADISE LANDSCAPES The novelty of Jan Brueghel’s (1568-1625) paradise landscapes lies in the impressive assemblage of animals depicted naturalistically and presented simultaneously as figures of a religious narrative and subjects of a scientific order. Brueghel’s paintings represent cultural attitudes towards nature, such as the taxonomic schemes of natural history catalogues of the time. The categories employed by contemporary naturalists to characterize animals also reveal a pansophic approach; they defined species in terms of their literary, biblical, or morphological associations. Brueghel, like the sixteenth-century natural historians Conrad Gesner and Ulisse Aldrovandi, combined empirical methods with textual knowledge to achieve a comprehensive and veristic representation of animals that incorporated different systems of belief. Brueghel’s development of the paradise landscape, which paralleled his encounters with patrons and collectors who had a keen interest in nature, reveals the evolution of his descriptive and cataloguing approach in which he applied the prevalent scientific and religious schemes of ordering the universe. His paintings chronologically follow Ulisse Aldrovandi’s methodology in which description leads to definition, definition to classification, and classification to knowledge. Furthermore, by depicting animals’ behavior and natural habitats, Brueghel translated the written information in natural history catalogues into a pictorial format. The naturalistic description of animals formed the basis of Brueghel’s approach, but his ultimate quest for an appropriate framework within which to present species led to his formulation of an encyclopedic representation that incorporated the scientific, religious, courtly, and artistic language of his time. PREFACE My research on Jan Brueghel’s paradise landscapes grew out of five years of practically living with his Entry o f the Animals into Noah's Ark in the J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles. The more I studied the painting the more I realized how little we know about the artist, in particular his approach to nature. The extant literature on Jan Brueghel the Elder does not include a careful examination of his paradise landscapes and animal representations. Klaus Ertz, in his monograph on the artist and in the recent exhibition catalogue Breughel-Brueghel, has never done more than present a straightforward formalistic analysis of Brueghel's oeuvre. His catalogue raisonne is a good reference book and starting point, despite some of his questionable attributions. The catalogue of Flemish paintings in the Prado Museum by Matias Diaz Padron is useful, because it addresses some of these problems of attribution and attempts to clarify them. More work has been done on Brueghel’s flower paintings, the most important of which is by Beatrijs Brenninkmeyer-De Rooij, who examines his working methods and discusses the artist’s juxtaposition of copies after botanical prints and studies from nature. Matthias Winner’s lengthy articles on the drawings are somewhat comprehensive except for the absence of the sketches of animals that I found most useful to my research. Important documentation exists in the form of Brueghel’s letters to Cardinal Borromeo, published by Giovanni Crivelli. Jean Denuce and Charles Duvivier compiled other letters and documentation revealing some of the activities of Brueghel and his son Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. A thorough analysis of Brueghel's landscapes and flower paintings in the collection of Borromeo appears in Pamela Jones’s book Federico Borromeo and the Ambrosiana. She explains how these works can be understood within the context of the Cardinal’s religious and aesthetic views. Finally, Stefania Bedoni attempted to reconstruct the painter’s travels throughout Italy as well as Italian collectors’ interest in his work. I have consulted many relevant scholars to whom I am grateful for their expertise. Numerous discussions with Lee Hendrix have helped me unravel the connection between Hoefnagel and Brueghel. Fritz Koreny, the foremost expert on nature imagery in Northern Renaissance art, has discussed his ideas about artists’ nature studies with me on separate occasions. Further reproduction prohibited without permission. 1 INTRODUCTION Jan Brueghel the Elder (1568-1625) popularized the “paradise landscape,” a relatively new sub-genre of landscape painting in the early seventeenth century, which typically represents episodes from Genesis. In Brueghel's works, a multitude of exotic and native European species coexist harmoniously in a lush landscape setting. While he studied the majority of the animals from life, he also selectively imitated artistic sources. In the early modem period, the naturalistic representation of animals did not always depend solely on direct observation, but on artistic knowledge and interpretation as well. Insofar as the descriptive process was not necessarily synonymous with objective viewing, Brueghel’s interpretative description encodes cultural attitudes towards nature, such as the taxonomic schemes of natural history catalogues of the time. These contributed to the complexity of his pictorial negotiation of multiple paradigms. The novelty of Brueghel's paradise landscapes lies in the impressive assemblage of animals studied mainly from life and presented simultaneously as figures of a religious narrative and subjects of a scientific order. The examination of this combination of approaches forms the basis of my dissertation. Despite a common biblical subject matter, the few earlier paradise landscapes by Hieronymus Bosch and Lucas Cranach I differ from Brueghel’s paintings in their imaginary and Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner.
